displaytitle: Portrait of a helmeted man, after a Greek original of ca. 460 B.C.
creditline: Gift of Edward Sampson, Class of 1914, for the Alden Sampson Collection

titles.title: Portrait of a helmeted man, after a mid-5th-century BCE Greek original

texts.textentryhtml: Given to the Museum by Edward Sampson
texts.remarks: Batch edit for Provenance publiation project 10/2023; created in project follow-up - FLB

texts.textentryhtml: The Romans developed a visual culture that engaged with the history of Greek art, using Greek originals as sources for imitation and innovation. The portrait of a helmeted man features a beard, visor, and direct stare that are reminiscent of portraits of the fifth-century BCE Athenian statesman Perikles, whom the Romans celebrated for his leadership during what they perceived to be a “Golden Age” of Athenian history. Roman artists also drew on Greek artistic styles for creating original works, such as the head of a youth, which exhibits features, including the eclectic and elaborate hairstyle, that are associated with many Archaic and early Classical Greek statues. The woman seen here wears a peplos, a style of clothing worn by Greek women that went out of fashion in the fifth century BCE. It likely could only have been known to the Roman sculptor through an earlier Greek prototype.
texts.remarks: MED_22-T2-2_CLA.pdf – Day One Cataloguing (group chat for y1962-132, y1991-43, 2016-374)

displayperiod: Roman Imperial Period, Julio-Claudian Period, 27–68 CE, ca. 30 BCE–476 CE
caption: Roman, Roman Imperial Period, Julio-Claudian Period, 27–68 CE (ca. 30 BCE–476 CE), Roman Empire, Portrait of a helmeted man, after a Greek original of ca. 460 B.C. Fine-grained gray marble, possibly Pentelic; 29 x 17.7 x 8.8 cm. Gift of Edward Sampson, Class of 1914, for the Alden Sampson Collection (y1962-132)
